text: hey guys Thomas Joseph here and today we
are tackling the twice-baked cookie and
that is the Scottie now typically for
people the complaints that they say are
that they're too crumbly they break
apart when you go to enjoy them or
they're so hard that they break your
teeth so today I'm going to share with
you a really great recipe for a
chocolate hazelnut biscotti that is
delicious it's still twice baked but it
will not break your teeth and it will
not crumble in your hand now in the bowl
of a food processor I have two and a
quarter cups of all-purpose flour and I
really love this recipe because you kind
of dump everything into this food
processor and mix it all up to that I'm
gonna add one and a half cups of roasted
hazelnuts that the skins have been
removed so they're going right into the
food processor here to this I'm gonna
add a quarter of a cup of Dutch process
cocoa powder and you guys if you
remember Dutch process cocoa powder is
cocoa powder that's been treated with an
alkaline solution so its pH is neutral
and it has a really dark brown color to
it different from the natural cocoa
powder so that goes into the food
processor here I'm going to add a
teaspoon of coarse salt and whenever
we're baking or creating recipes here at
Martha Stewart Living we typically use
coarse salt not fine salt so make sure
you follow the recipe and one teaspoon
of baking soda in addition to this I'm
gonna add six ounces of semi-sweet
chocolate that's cut into chunks you
could certainly use the chocolate chips
if you have those on hand but this is
going into the food processor here and
I'm going to pulse this together to
break up the nuts in the chocolate a
little bit until they're about the size
of a small pea
so you can see here there are nice
pieces of hazelnut and chocolate still
left because you do want some texture
here and the cocoa powder has been
evenly distributed with the flour and
you get this nice buck weedy color here
and I'm gonna put this off to the side
leave it right there while I prepare the
eggs for the biscotti now what I really
love about this recipe is that it uses
no fat biscotti is traditionally a very
lean cookie meaning that there's not
much fat that's added other than what's
naturally occurring in the egg yolks and
the chocolate here we're going to whip
the eggs with the sugar and we're gonna
create a very velvety ribbony lofty
mixture that we're gonna fold our dry
ingredients into so it adds a bit of
lightness to the cookie which i think is
great I'm going to whip these up
slightly just breaking the yolks apart
and mixing them in with the whites you
want this to get a little bit frothy now
I'm going to add one and a half cups of
granulated sugar and the slowly add this
into the eggs while whipping and what
this is gonna do is it's gonna dissolve
the sugar into the eggs and these eggs
are gonna build in volume as we whip
them and that's really what we're
looking for here and that's gonna add
the loftiness the lightness to our
biscotti so it's been about four minutes
you can see how light and pale the
mixture gets and it's quite voluminous
now I'm gonna take off the wire whisk
attachment and I'm gonna transfer to the
paddle attachment but just so I can show
you guys what I mean when I say light
and ribbony if you take the wire whisk
and you pull it up on the batter it
should leave a slight ribbon in the
batter so this looks perfect here and
now I'm going to put it back onto the
mixer paddle attachment and I'm going to
take the mixture that we ground up in
the food processor I'm going to add it
in you can just add it all at once and
remember guys when you're using your
food processor if you stick your finger
into the back of the food processor bowl
here and hold the blade it won't tumble
out on you which is a really great
safety tip
that goes in and a reserved quantity of
semi-sweet chocolates 6 ounces again so
the other half of the chocolate goes
right in and I'm going to just mix this
until it's nicely combined you don't
want to over beat this because you don't
want to really beat out all of the
volume that you just created with your
wire whisk attachment so just until the
mixture is nice and combined and now I'm
going to scrape down the paddle
attachment and shape this into the logs
for the first bacon alright so now it's
time to shape the biscotti so I'm gonna
take a quarter of the dough at a time
here because this makes four biscotti
logs
and just using my work surface here I'm
gonna flour my hands slightly and just
shape this into a two by ten inch log so
this looks pretty good I'm gonna
transfer this onto my parchment lined
baking sheet and this will expand quite
a bit guys so give it a little bit of
room I'm gonna do one more batch you
should be able to fit two of these logs
on a sheet tray like this and have your
oven preheating to 350 degrees with the
racks in the upper and lower third
because this will make for logs as I had
said so you're gonna need two sheet
trays here so now to embellish the top
of the biscotti I'm gonna take a little
bit of egg white that I've just whipped
up with a fork slightly just broken it
apart a little bit
brush the top of your log and then to
give it a little bit of a special touch
sprinkle with some coarse sanding sugar
now you could use fine sanding sugar you
can use turbinado sugar the sugar and
the raw this goes into a 350 degree oven
for about 20 to 24 minutes until they're
firm to the touch you don't want really
that much color on these you just want
to pre-bake them so the biscotti have
baked for 20 to 24 minutes and they've
cooled now for about 20 minutes you
don't want to cut them when they're
piping hot or they'll fall apart so
these have cooled slightly so transfer
these tube
a cutting board and you're gonna cut
these into three-quarter inch pieces and
then these are gonna go back into the
oven for about 20 more minutes until the
cookie itself is dry to the touch and
you can see when you cut them they're
still really moist and wet in the center
and really we're looking to dry the
cookies out a little bit but we don't
want them to be void of any sort of
moisture because we don't want them to
be too toothsome or crumbly so I like to
cook these on a baking sheet with a wire
rack so that there's even air
circulation so if you have one of these
baking racks that fits into your sheet
tray that's really great now of course
I'm using the classic combination of
chocolate and hazelnut today but you
really could take this recipe and adapt
it and add in other ingredients if you
like so if you wanted some sour cherries
which would really offset the nuttiness
and the fattiness of the chocolate that
would be fantastic and I'm using a
serrated knife to cut through these
cookies and it's best to use a serrated
knife here because it really does cut
through the nuts in the chocolate chunks
nice and evenly and it won't encourage
your cookie to crumble or crack so place
these on your tray alright so right back
into the oven 350 degrees 20 minutes
until they're firm to the touch in the
center but not dry as a bone guys so our
biscotti and they're out of the oven
they're completely cooled twice cooked
and ready to serve or you guys you can
store these up to I would say two weeks
in an airtight container and I just want
to show you the texture again these
aren't crumbly they're not gonna break
your tooth you can see how amazing they
are
now we've answered one of your
